question: Question 20 Consider a 5-stage pipelined processor with Instruction Fetch (IF), Instruction Decode (ID), Execute (EX), Memory Access (MEM), and Register Writeback (WB) stages. Which of the following statements about forwarding is/are CORRECT?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A:
In a pipelined execution, forwarding means the result from a source stage of an
earlier instruction is passed on to the destination stage of a later instruction
options.B:
In forwarding, data from the output of the MEM stage can be passed on to the
input of the EX stage of the next instruction
options.C: Forwarding cannot prevent all pipeline stalls
options.D:
Forwarding does not require any extra hardware to retrieve the data from the
pipeline stages

Question 26 Consider a network path [latex]\mathrm{P}-\mathrm{Q}-\mathrm{R} [/latex] between nodes [latex]\mathrm{P} [/latex] and [latex]\mathrm{R} [/latex] via router [latex]\mathrm{Q} [/latex]. Node [latex]P [/latex] sends these chunks one after the other without any wait time between the successive chunk transmissions. Assume that the size of extra headers added to these chunks is negligible, and that the chunk size is less than the MTU. Each of the links [latex]\mathrm{P}-\mathrm{Q} [/latex] and [latex]\mathrm{Q}-\mathrm{R} [/latex] has a bandwidth of [latex]10^6 \mathrm{bits} / \mathrm{sec} [/latex], and negligible propagation latency. Router [latex]Q [/latex] immediately transmits every packet it receives from [latex]P [/latex] to [latex]R [/latex], with negligible processing and queueing delays. Router [latex]Q [/latex] can simultaneously receive on link [latex]P-Q [/latex] and transmit on [latex]\operatorname{link} Q-R [/latex]. Assume P starts transmitting the chunks at time [latex]t=0 [/latex].
Which one of the following options gives the time (in seconds, rounded off to 3 decimal places) at which [latex]\mathrm{R} [/latex] receives all the chunks of the file?

Question 29 Consider the following pseudo-code. [latex]
\begin{array}{ll}
L 1: & t 1=-1 \\
L 2: & t 2=0 \\

L 5: & t 5=4 * t 2 \\
L 6: & t 6=t 5 * M \\
L 7: & t 7=t 4+t 6 \\
L 8: & t 8=a[t 7] \\
L 9: & if \; t 8 \lt = max  \; goto  \; L 11 \\
L 10: & t 1=t 8 \\
L 11: & t 3=t 3+1 \\
L 12: & if  \; t 3 \lt M  \;  goto L 4 \\
L 13: & t 2=t 2+1 \\
L 14: & if  \; t 2 \lt N  \; goto  \; L 3 \\

\end{array}

question:
Question 43 Consider two set-associative cache memory architectures: WBC, which uses the
write back policy, and WTC, which uses the write through policy. Both of them use
the LRU (Least Recently Used) block replacement policy. The cache memory is
connected to the main memory. Which of the following statements is/are TRUE?
solution: Click here for detail solution by gateoverflow

options.A: A read miss in WBC never evicts a dirty block
options.B:
A read miss in WTC never triggers a write back operation of a cache block to
main memory
options.C: A write hit in WBC can modify the value of the dirty bit of a cache block
options.D:
A write miss in WTC always writes the victim cache block to main memory
before loading the missed block to the cache
